bibl.title: Letter from Michael E. Connor to Henry Rose Carter, June 27, 1923

div1.p: Connor writes that he is using soap as a larvacide in water, and it is proving very effective with Aedes aegypti, but not Culex larvae.

div1.head: Letter from Michael E. Connor to Henry Rose Carter, June 27, 1923
div1.opener:
PODER EJECUTIVO FEDERAL
ESTADOS-UNIDOS-MEXICANOS
MEXICO
DEPARTAMENTO
DE
SALUBRIDAD PUBLICA
----
COMICION ESPECIAL PARA LA CAMPAÑA
CONTRA LA FIEBRE AMARILLA
----
PRIMERA ZONA
----
TAMPICO, TAMAULIPAS
I. H. B.
Lejia
Tampico Tamps.
June 27th. 1923.
Dear Doctor Carter:
div1.p:
You will be interested to know that in the Colima
area soap is being used as a larvacide in mosquito-
proofing lejia (agua de ceniza) containers and the re-
sults have been 100%.

For the past week the same measure has been in
Tampico and with excellent results so much so that the
sanitary inspectors no longer carry oil with them as
formerly when we depended upon kerosene to kill the lar-
vae in lejia containers.

I am certainly glad that you suggessted the use
of soap for the lejias. It seemingly will solve the
problem which has been not only annoying but quite
expensive to handle since the begining of the present
campaign. Am suggessting to the Board that they publish
in the quarterly bulletin a short note regarding the
soap measure so that our men elsewhere may try out the
same.

Here follows a typical experiment with soap in lejia.
"several small larvae, on of which was near pupation
and two pupae were placed in the usual tin used for
stowing lejia. A small quantity of the popular brand
of laundry soap was introduced by rubbing between
the hands with repeated immersions into the lejia.
I estimate the amount of soap used as equal to that
used by the average person in washing their hands.
The result to the lejia was that it assumed a gray
color without suds being formed.

Within two minutes after the introduction of the
soap the larvae became wildly agitated and at no
time did they seek the sides of the container but moved
rapidly to and fro in the center of the container,
and never once they did they adopt the breathing
position.

In a short timev the larvae sank to the bottom of the
container at varying intervals until death ensued
when some of them floated to the surface of the
lejia.

The addition of the soap appears to hasten pupation
and the pupae resists the mixtures for several hours
but in no instance did they survive longer than 24
hours. Thiss data applies only to aedes egypti larvae
-2-
Culex larvae do appear to be disturbed in the leastv by the
addition of the soap. I suppose this is because they are a hardier
insect than the stegomyia and more quickly adapt themselves to new
surroundings.

For the moment the housewives furnish the soap but am planning
further experiments with liquid soap as well as with soap chips
and will advise you later of the results. It is worth recording
that the washerwomen are emiently satisfied with this measure as
compared with the oil, copper plates or fruit skins.
With all good wishes, I am,
div1.closer:
very sincerely yours, M E Connor. Dr. H.R. Carter
#2121 California St. N.W.
Washington, D.C.
